questions.text: A surgeon is performing a dissection in the shoulder region and notes the structures passing through the clavipectoral fascia. Which of the following structures is known to pierce the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thoracoacromial Artery

 

Option B.

 

  • This is the correct answer.
  • The thoracoacromial artery, a branch of the axillary artery, pierces the clavipectoral fascia and divides into several branches that supply the shoulder region, including the pectoral, acromial, clavicular, and deltoid branches.

 

Clavipectoral Fascia: Fascia between clavicle & pectoralis minor muscle is known as Clavipectoral fascia.

 

 

Four notable structures that pierce the clavipectoral fascia are:

 

  1. Thoracoacromial Artery: This artery is a branch of the axillary artery and pierces the fascia to supply the pectoralis major, deltoid, and other muscles in the shoulder area.
  2. Lateral Pectoral Nerve: This nerve, which innervates the pectoralis major muscle, pierces the clavipectoral fascia to reach its target muscle.
  3. Cephalic Vein: The cephalic vein travels through the deltopectoral groove and pierces the clavipectoral fascia to drain into the axillary vein. It is a significant landmark in surgical procedures of the shoulder.
  4. Lymphatics from the Axillary Lymph Nodes: Lymph vessels associated with the axillary lymph nodes, important for lymphatic drainage from the upper limb and breast, pierce the fascia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • The axillary nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia.
  • It travels through the quadrangular space and is primarily associated with the innervation of the deltoid and teres minor muscles.

 

Option C.

 

  • The suprascapular artery, while important in the shoulder region, does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia.
  • It travels above the scapula and supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles.

 

Option D.

 

  • This nerve runs superficial to the clavipectoral fascia.
  • It innervates the serratus anterior muscle and is known for its vulnerability in surgical procedures in the axillary region, but it does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clavipectoral fascia serves as a key landmark for identifying these structures during surgical dissections and interventions.
  • The thoracoacromial artery is the structure that pierces the clavipectoral fascia.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a procedure in the anterior axillary region and observes the clavipectoral fascia enclosing the pectoralis minor muscle. As the surgeon dissects further, they note that this fascia continues distally beyond the pectoralis minor. What does the clavipectoral fascia become after enclosing the pectoralis minor muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspensory ligament

 

Option D:

 

  • Suspensory Ligament, also known as the costoclavicular ligament or ligament of Gerdy.
  • It is sometimes considered an extension of the clavipectoral fascia.
  • It extends from the axillary fascia and suspends the axillary fascia and overlying skin.
  • After enclosing the pectoralis minor, the clavipectoral fascia extends inferiorly as the suspensory ligament of the axilla.
  • This ligament helps to support the axillary fascia and is particularly noticeable when the upper limb is raised.

 

Suspensory ligament of axilla extends from lower border of pectoralis minor to base of axilla.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Axillary sheath is derived from the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia.
  • It is a fascial sleeve that surrounds the neurovascular bundle (the axillary artery, axillary vein, and the brachial plexus) in the axilla.
  • While the axillary sheath is in the same region as the clavipectoral fascia, it is not a direct continuation of the clavipectoral fascia.
  • The axillary sheath is more associated with the neurovascular structures of the axilla.

 

Option B.

 

  • Costocoracoid ligament extends from the coracoid process to the first costochondral junction.

 

Option C.

 

  • Costoclavicular ligament extends from the first rib and its cartilage to the sternal end of the clavicle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Suspensory Ligament, also known as the costoclavicular ligament or ligament of Gerdy.
  • It is sometimes considered an extension of the clavipectoral fascia.
  • It extends from the axillary fascia and suspends the axillary fascia and overlying skin.
  • After enclosing the pectoralis minor, the clavipectoral fascia extends inferiorly as the suspensory ligament of the axilla.
  • This ligament helps to support the axillary fascia and is particularly noticeable when the upper limb is raised.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 33

choices.text: Axillary tail of Spence is in contact with anterior group of axillary lymph nodes
Retromammary space intervenes between deep fascia of pectoral region and pectoralis major muscle
External oblique aponeurosis separates the breast from rectus abdominis muscle
Suspensory ligaments of cooper extends from skin to the underlying pectoral fascia

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came to the surgeon with complaints of a hard, painless lump in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The axillary nodes on the right side were enlarged and there was loss of mobility of the breast. X-ray of the vertebral column showed irregular shadows in the bodies of L1 & L2 vertebra. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retromammary space intervenes between deep fascia of pectoral region and pectoralis major muscle

 

Option B.

 

  • The retromammary space is an anatomical space located between the breast tissue and the pectoralis major muscle.
  • The deep fascia of the pectoral region is what lies directly over the pectoralis major muscle. The retromammary space is actually between the breast tissue and the pectoral fascia, not between the deep fascia of the pectoral region and the pectoralis major muscle.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • This is an extension of the glandular tissue of the breast that extends into the axilla.
  • The axillary tail of Spence is indeed in close proximity to the axillary lymph nodes, particularly the anterior group.
  • These lymph nodes are a primary route for lymphatic drainage from the breast, making them clinically significant, especially in breast cancer cases.

 

Option C.

 

  • External oblique aponeurosis is a strong, flat sheet of fibrous tissue that forms part of the abdominal wall. The external oblique aponeurosis lies superficial to the rectus abdominis muscle.
  • The lower portion of the breast lies above this aponeurosis. While it does not directly separate the breast from the rectus abdominis muscle, it is part of the layered structure of the anterior abdominal wall in which the breast is located.

 

Option D.

 

  • Suspensory ligaments of cooper are fibrous bands that traverse the breast tissue, providing support. They extend from the dermis of the skin through the breast tissue and attach to the deep fascia.
  • Their role is to maintain the structural integrity and shape of the breast. They do indeed extend to the underlying pectoral fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retromammary Space Intervenes Between Deep Fascia of Pectoral Region and Pectoralis Major Muscle:

 

  • The retromammary space is an anatomical space located between the breast tissue and the pectoralis major muscle.
  • The deep fascia of the pectoral region is what lies directly over the pectoralis major muscle. The retromammary space is actually between the breast tissue and the pectoral fascia, not between the deep fascia of the pectoral region and the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 945
